    "let @xmath0 be a commutative ring with @xmath1 .",
    "write @xmath2 : = \\ { 1,2 , \\ldots , n\\}$ ] .",
    "let @xmath3 denote the graded exterior algebra over @xmath0 generated by @xmath1 and degree - one elements @xmath4 for @xmath5 $ ] .",
    "define a @xmath0-linear map @xmath6 by @xmath7 , @xmath8 for @xmath5 $ ] , and @xmath9 for @xmath10 and @xmath11 $ ] .",
    "let @xmath12 be a loopless matroid on @xmath2 $ ] with rank @xmath13 .",
    "the orlik - solomon algebra of @xmath12 is the quotient @xmath14 of @xmath15 by the ideal @xmath16 generated by @xmath17 for every circuit @xmath18 of @xmath12 .    if @xmath1 and @xmath19 are parallel , that is , @xmath20 is a circuit , then @xmath21 . so the orlik - solomon algebra of the simple matroid associated with @xmath12 is equal to that of @xmath12 .",
    "the orlik - solomon algebra @xmath14 has the natural grading .",
    "the linear map @xmath22 on @xmath15 induces the linear map @xmath23 on @xmath14 .",
    "let @xmath24 .",
    "we call @xmath25 a weight of @xmath12 .",
    "the left multiplication @xmath26 induces the complex @xmath27 .",
    "let @xmath28 denote the cohomology of this complex .",
    "if @xmath29 then @xmath28 is just @xmath14 , otherwise we have @xmath30 . if @xmath31 then we have @xmath32 for all @xmath33 ( see @xcite ) . if @xmath34 then @xmath35 induces the complex @xmath36 and the cohomology @xmath37 , where @xmath38 is the image of @xmath23",
    "it is known that @xmath39 for a generic weight @xmath40 , yuzvinsky @xcite showed the vanishing theorem : @xmath41 and hence we have @xmath42    an arrangement @xmath43 of hyperplanes in @xmath44 has the underlying matroid @xmath45 with rank @xmath13 as a combinatorial structure .",
    "the cohomology of the complement of @xmath43 is isomorphic to @xmath38 ( see @xcite and @xcite ) .",
    "if a weight @xmath46 satisfies some generic condition , then the cohomology of the complement of @xmath43 with the coefficients in the rank one local system associated to @xmath40 is isomorphic to @xmath37 ( see @xcite ) . the local system cohomologys is an important subject in the multivariable theory of hypergeometric functions @xcite . by the vanishing theorem @xcite , for a generic weight @xmath40",
    ", the local system cohomology vanishes in all but the top dimension . in this paper ,",
    "our purpose is to construct matroids and arrangements with non - vanishing cohomology of orlik - solomon algebras , or rather @xmath47 .    in particular , the case of @xmath48",
    "was studied in @xcite .",
    "falk @xcite defined the _ resonance variety _ , that is , the space of weights with non - vanishing cohomology .",
    "the resonance variety is deeply related to the cohomology support loci @xcite and the characteristic variety @xcite .",
    "libgober and yuzvinsky @xcite showed that , under some condition , weights with non - vanishing first cohomology are parametrized by latin squares .    in this paper , we prove that , in general , matroids associated to latin hypercubes have weights with non - vanishing cohomology , by using decomposable relations arising from latin hypercubes .",
    "this decomposable relation is the generalization of the relation discovered by rybnikov ( see @xcite ) .",
    "moreover , in the case of @xmath48 , we study well , using terms of latin squares . in the last section , we shall give examples of realizations including the higher case .",
    "some of them appear in the classical projective geometry ( see figure [ fig : pappus ] , [ fig : kirkman ] and [ fig : steiner ] ) .",
    "we shall use the following notation and terminology .",
    "a @xmath49-set is a set with cardinality @xmath49 .",
    "denote the family of all @xmath49-subset of a set @xmath50 by @xmath51 .",
    "often , we regard a @xmath33-tuple @xmath52 as a @xmath33-set @xmath53 . we refer to @xcite for terminology of the matroid theory .",
    "a latin hypercube of dimension @xmath54 and order @xmath55 is an @xmath56-array such that , if @xmath57 coordinates are fixed , the @xmath55 positions so determined contain a permutation of @xmath55 symbols .",

    "we refer to @xcite for the latin squares . a _ latin square _ of order @xmath55 is a latin hypercube of dimension 2 and order @xmath55 , that is , an @xmath190 matrix with entries in an @xmath55-set ( we call the _ symbol set_. ) such that each element occurs exactly once in each row and exactly once in each column . the two latin squares @xmath64 and @xmath191 are _ isotopic _ if @xmath191 is obtained by permutations of rows , permutations of columns , and a bijection from the symbol set of @xmath64 .",
    "let @xmath192 , @xmath193 and @xmath194 be three @xmath55-sets and let @xmath64 be a latin square with rows indexed by @xmath192 , columns by @xmath193 , and symbols by @xmath194 .",
    "define @xmath195 .",
    "for any permutation @xmath196 of @xmath197 , the @xmath196-_conjugate _ of @xmath198 is the latin square @xmath199 with rows indexed by @xmath200 , columns by @xmath201 , and symbols by @xmath202 , defined by @xmath203 .",
    "the two latin squares @xmath64 and @xmath191 are _ main class isotopic _ if @xmath191 is isotopic to any conjugate of @xmath64 .",

    ". if @xmath214 and @xmath215 are main class isotopic latin squares then matroids @xmath216 $ ] and @xmath217 $ ] are isomorphic .",

    "it is clear by the definition of main class isotopic latin squares .",

    "a set of latin squares of order @xmath55 is _ mutually orthogonal _ if any two distinct squares are orthogonal .",

    "we note that there are degenerations of matroids associated to latin square with non - vanishing cohomology , except for those of proposition [ prop : deg1 ] and [ prop : deg2 ] . especially , it is not necessary to be simple , for example , see section [ arr : deg ] .",
    "for a matroid @xmath12 , an arrangement over a field @xmath325 with underlying matroid @xmath12 is called a @xmath325-_realization _ or _ representation _ of @xmath12 .",
    "a matroid is said to be _",
    "realizable _ or _",
    "representable _ over @xmath325 if @xmath12 has a @xmath325-realization .",
    "we shall find realizations of matroids obtained in the previous section . in this section",
    ", we will know the following :      in addition , these realizations are arrangements appearing in the classical projective geometry ( figure [ fig : pappus ] , [ fig : kirkman ] and [ fig : steiner ] ) . besides , we shall give many other examples including the higher case .",
    "we have only one main class isotopic latin square @xmath329 .",
    "the decomposable relation is @xmath330 .",
    "the matroid @xmath73 $ ] is realized by the arrangement in @xmath293 arising from the ceva theorem ( the left side in figure [ fig : pappus ] ) .",
    "we have only one main class isotopic latin square , which is given by @xmath332 =   \\begin{bmatrix }    ( 1,4,7 ) & ( 1,5,8 ) & ( 1,6,9 ) \\\\     ( 2,4,9 ) & ( 2,5,7 ) & ( 2,6,8 ) \\\\     ( 3,4,8 ) & ( 3,5,9 ) & ( 3,6,7 )    \\end{bmatrix}.\\ ] ] the realization is given by the arrangement of 9 lines in @xmath293 arising from the pappus theorem ( the right side in figure [ fig : pappus ] ) .",
    "there are two main class isotopic latin squares , that we can give by @xmath334 =   \\begin{bmatrix }    ( 1,5,9 )   & ( 1,6,10 ) & ( 1,7,11 ) & ( 1,8,12 )   \\\\     ( 2,5,12 ) & ( 2,6,9 )   & ( 2,7,10 ) & ( 2,8,11 )   \\\\     ( 3,5,11 ) & ( 3,6,12 ) & ( 3,7,9 )   & ( 3,8,10 )   \\\\     ( 4,5,10 ) & ( 4,6,11 ) & ( 4,7,12 ) & ( 4,8,9 )     \\end{bmatrix},\\ ] ] @xmath335 =   \\begin{bmatrix }    ( 1,5,9 )   & ( 1,6,10 ) & ( 1,7,11 ) & ( 1,8,12 )   \\\\     ( 2,5,10 ) & ( 2,6,9 )   & ( 2,7,12 ) & ( 2,8,11 )   \\\\     ( 3,5,11 ) & ( 3,6,12 ) & ( 3,7,9 )   & ( 3,8,10 )   \\\\     ( 4,5,12 ) & ( 4,6,11 ) & ( 4,7,10 ) & ( 4,8,9 )     \\end{bmatrix}.\\ ] ] the matroid @xmath216 $ ] or @xmath217 $ ] is realized by the arrangement of 12 lines in @xmath293 defined by figure [ fig : kirkman ] or [ fig : steiner ] , which is arising from the kirkman theorem or the steiner theorem , respectively ( see ( * ? ? ? * chapter 16 ) ) .",

    "this matroid @xmath344 $ ] is realized by the arrangement of 11 lines in @xmath345 with the infinite line @xmath1 in figure [ fig : dkirkman ] .        the degeneration of @xmath217 $ ] such that @xmath1 and @xmath19 are parallel , that is , @xmath20 is a circuit , has a realization defined by the left one in figure [ fig : dsteiner ] .",
    "moreover , the degeneration of @xmath217 $ ] such that @xmath20 , @xmath346 and @xmath347 are circuits , is realizable .",
    "this realization is the @xmath348-arrangement ( the right one in figure [ fig : dsteiner ] ) .",
    "therefore , these two arrangements have weights with non - vanishing first cohomology in the same way of remark [ rem:3 ] .          two latin squares @xmath350 are mutually orthogonal .",
    "we have @xmath351 =   \\begin{bmatrix }    ( 1,4,7 ) & ( 1,5,8 ) & ( 1,6,9 )   \\\\     ( 2,4,9 ) & ( 2,5,7 ) & ( 2,6,8 )   \\\\     ( 3,4,8 ) & ( 3,5,9 ) & ( 3,6,7 )    \\end{bmatrix } , \\   { { \\mathcal c}}[k_2 ] =   \\begin{bmatrix }    ( 1,4,10 ) & ( 1,5,11 ) & ( 1,6,12 ) \\\\     ( 2,4,11 ) & ( 2,5,12 ) & ( 2,6,10 ) \\\\     ( 3,4,12 ) & ( 3,5,10 ) & ( 3,6,11 )    \\end{bmatrix}.\\ ] ] the matroid @xmath352 $ ] is @xmath353 ( see @xcite ) and realized as the hessian configuration .",
    "the hessian configuration is the arrangement of 12 projective lines passing through the nine inflection points of a nonsingular cubic in @xmath354 ( * ? ? ?",
    "* example 6.30 ) , which we can define by lines @xmath355",
    "@xmath356 @xmath357 @xmath358 where @xmath359 .",
    "underlying matroids of arrangements @xmath360 are @xmath216 $ ] and @xmath217 $ ] , respectively .",
    "the hessian configuration @xmath361 has the underlying matroid @xmath352 $ ] and we have @xmath362 ) , e_{\\lambda } ) } = 2 $ ] for a non - zero one - form @xmath363 with @xmath364 .",
    "let @xmath64 be the latin square of order @xmath55 defined by the addition table for @xmath365 for @xmath70 .",
    "the monomial arrangement @xmath366 in @xmath367 is given by the defining polynomial @xmath368 set @xmath369 .",
    "define @xmath370 for @xmath371 .",
    "so we have @xmath372 .",
    "since @xmath373 has rank two , the underlying matroid @xmath374 of @xmath375 is isomorphic to the uniform matroid @xmath376 of rank two .",
    "another rank two intersections are @xmath377 for @xmath378 .",
    "hence , @xmath64 can be consider as the latin square with rows indexed by @xmath379 , columns by @xmath380 , and symbols by @xmath381 .",
    "the underlying matroid of @xmath366 is the matroid @xmath382 $ ] . by proposition",
    "[ prop : deg1 ] , @xmath366 has weights with non - vanishing first cohomology .",
    "( 130 , 60)(0,0 ) ( 0,30 ) ( 20,10 ) 1 ( 0,0 ) ( 20,10 ) 2 ( 40,0 ) ( 20,10 ) 1 ( 40,30 ) ( 20,10 ) 2 ( 70,47 ) ( 20,10 ) 2 ( 70,17 ) ( 20,10 ) 1 ( 110,17 ) ( 20,10 ) 2 ( 110,47 ) ( 20,10 ) 1 ( 22,5)(1,0)20 ( 22,35)(1,0)20 ( 12,30)(0,-1)20 ( 52,30)(0,-1)20 ( 92,22)(1,0)20 ( 92,52)(1,0)20 ( 80,47)(0,-1)20 ( 120,47)(0,-1)20 ( 22,5)(3,1)50 ( 22,35)(3,1)50 ( 62,5)(3,1)50 ( 62,35)(3,1)50    ( 130 , 60)(0,0 ) ( 0,30 ) ( 20,10 ) 1357 ( 0,0 ) ( 20,10 ) 2358 ( 40,0 ) ( 20,10 ) 2457 ( 40,30 ) ( 20,10 ) 1458 ( 70,47 ) ( 20,10 ) 1368 ( 70,17 ) ( 20,10 ) 2367 ( 110,17 ) ( 20,10 ) 2468 ( 110,47 ) ( 20,10 ) 1467 ( 22,5)(1,0)20 ( 22,35)(1,0)20 ( 12,30)(0,-1)20 ( 52,30)(0,-1)20 ( 92,22)(1,0)20 ( 92,52)(1,0)20 ( 80,47)(0,-1)20 ( 120,47)(0,-1)20 ( 22,5)(3,1)50 ( 22,35)(3,1)50 ( 62,5)(3,1)50 ( 62,35)(3,1)50    the matroid @xmath73 $ ] is the matroid of type @xmath385 in ( * ? ? ? * p.510 ) .",
    "let @xmath43 be an @xmath386-arrangement defined by the defining polynomial @xmath387 where @xmath388 are distinct each other .",
    "by the simple computation , @xmath43 is a realization of @xmath73 $ ] .",
    "therefore , @xmath43 has weights with non - vanishing second cohomology .",
    "let @xmath389 be an @xmath386-arrangement defined by the defining polynomial @xmath390 by the simple computation , we can check that @xmath389 has no @xmath213-circuits and the family of @xmath386-circuits is @xmath65 \\cup \\ { ( 1,2,3,4 ) , ( 1,2,7,8 ) , ( 3,4,5,6 ) , ( 5,6,7,8 ) \\}.\\ ] ] therefore , @xmath389 has weights with non - vanishing second cohomology .",
    "a main part of this work was done while the author was visiting mathematical sciences research institute in august - november , 2004 .",
    "the author would like to thank msri for its hospitality .",
    "the author is grateful to professor sergey yuzvinsky and professor michael falk for many helpful suggestions and valuable discussions and the author would also like to thank professor hiroaki terao for his help .",
    "a.  libgober , _ characteristic varieties of algebraic curves _ , applications of algebraic geometry to coding theory , physics and computation ( eilat , 2001 ) , 215254 , nato sci .",
    ", 36 , kluwer acad .",
    "publ . , dordrecht , 2001 .            v.  v.  prasolov , _",
    "essays on numbers and figures _",
    ", translated from the 1997 russian original by a. b. sossinski .",
    "mathematical world , 16 .",
    "american mathematical society , providence , ri , 2000 .",
    "v.  schechtman , h.  terao and a.  varchenko , _ local systems over complements of hyperplanes and the kac - kazhdan conditions for singular vectors _ , j.  pure appl .",
    "algebra * 100 * ( 1995 ) , 93102 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> the cohomology on the complement of hyperplanes with the coefficients in the rank one local system associated to a generic weight vanishes except in the highest dimension . in this paper , we construct matroids or arrangements and its weights with non - vanishing cohomology of orlik - solomon algebras , using decomposable relations arising from latin hypercubes . </S>"
  ]
}
